item.title: Hawthorne Blvd, a photographic stroll
item.dc:creator: daybf
item.description: Portland is divided north to south by Burnside St and the Willamette river divides east and west. I primarily stayed on the west side, since my hotel was in the northwest and the transportation via the streetcar and the MAX get you everywhere on the west side. You have to take buses to get over [...]
item.content:encoded:
Portland is divided north to south by Burnside St and the Willamette river divides east and west. I primarily stayed on the west side, since my hotel was in the northwest and the transportation via the streetcar and the MAX get you everywhere on the west side. You have to take buses to get over the river (except for the airport and IKEA where the MAX goes). I knew I had to make my way over to the Hawthorne District in the southeast where all the hipsters hangout (supposedly). Kind of like the Mission District in San Francisco. I also heard Hawthorne Blvd. in particular be called the Haight-Ashbury of Portland. In any case, I took a bus over and got off at 30th and Hawthorne and walked down to about 41st where there seemed to be less to walk to and see.

The vibe was instantly different. A little grungier (in a normal city kind of way) and reminded me of my hometown Santa Cruz’s downtown.  Neat old buildings housed coffee shops, diners, boutiques. Unique privately owned stores promised one-of-a-kind finds, such as vintage clothing and vinyls. On this day I decided I would conquer my fear of photographing strangers. So, I made a promise to myself that I would ask at least one stranger if I could take their picture. It turns out I asked many  more and none of them said no! However, I also carefully chose who to ask.

I initially wanted to photograph some hipsters, since Shannon’s mom Sarah was still unsure of what a hipster was. But, it was 38 degrees and I think the hipsters were hiding (indoors). Or, were not simply roaming the streets on a Sunday like I was. I got to photograph super nice and interesting people, don’t get me wrong, but I was expecting more over-the-top hipsters. In any case, I’ll let my pictures speak for themselves now.

My first subjects were these teenagers in ghillie suits hiding in bushes and scaring pedestrians.

This violinist was super talented and taken aback when I asked if I could take his picture. He thanked me and said that most people don’t ask.
Doesn’t he have a great smile?
Another musician, who was very serious for someone who seemed to be a young teenager. But I’m bad with ages…

This man had a booth for PGE (Portland General Electric, too similar to PG&E) and I stopped and talked to him for awhile about this new thing you could sign up for to save energy, etc. Then he graciously let me take his photograph. Love the hat and beard, and check out those eyes of his!
I went into this herb shop to buy some loose leaf tea, and photographed the employee who had impressively long dreads. She was sweet and timid, but didn’t even flinch at the idea of having her photograph taken.

Most of the dogs I saw wore little coats to keep them warm, but this little guy had a furry parka!
I stopped at The Fresh Pot coffee shop inside of Powell’s Books on Hawthorne. When I asked this woman for her picture and gave her my spiel she just said “I used to do that.”

Caught a Powell’s Books employee on a smoke break. “Uh, sure you can take my picture…what should I do?” “Oh, you can just keep smoking.” But then he continued to look right at me, which was what I really wanted.
It was a nerve-racking day full of firsts and I was constantly amazed at how kind everyone I ran into was. I gave all of my subjects my business card and told them to contact me if they wanted to see/have their photographs. About 4 of them got back to me, which I was pleased with.

item.title: Tattoos: A 21st Century Perspective.
item.dc:creator: kendallgoodwin
item.description: via I have a fascination with tattoos. I’ve gotten really into reading the Tattoo Tuesday feature on Sometimes Sweet, and it’s so interesting to see so many different tattoos on so many different people, and to read about their significance and the process of being tattooed. I’ve been thinking a lot lately about the stigma [...]
item.content:encoded:
via

I have a fascination with tattoos. I’ve gotten really into reading the Tattoo Tuesday feature on Sometimes Sweet, and it’s so interesting to see so many different tattoos on so many different people, and to read about their significance and the process of being tattooed.

I’ve been thinking a lot lately about the stigma surrounding tattoos and how silly it is. Quick anecdote: toward the end of high school, I told my mom that I wanted to get a full sleeve tattoo (sort of joking) and she almost started crying. I think she was concerned that I a) wanted to ruin my body with tattoos, b) was being openly rebellious, and c) would never get a job if I had tattoos.

via

The distrust/suspicion of people with visible tattoos seems to be a generational thing: I know lots of people’s parents who think that tattoos are only for hoodrats, but very few people my own age who feel the same way. And while there are some instances in which tattoos are an act of rebellion, I think they more commonly serve as symbolic art. People get tattoos to commemorate life milestones, to remember their heritage or people they’ve lost, to remind themselves that they can be the best versions of themselves, to say with art what they can’t say verbally. There will always be nimrods who get dumb tattoos that don’t mean anything to them, but for the most part, getting a tattoo is often more intentional and thoughtful than that.

I think tattoos can be really beautiful, and I don’t think it detracts anything from a person when they have tattoos. It’s not like your personality does a 180 when you get a tattoo; of all the people I know with tattoos, they have all stayed the same people they were pre-tat. The only difference is that they have some amazing artwork on their body now. If you’re so focused on thinking that nice-looking people are “ruining” their bodies with tattoos, you’ll never be able to see the beauty and meaning in what they’ve chosen to make part of their body. And as for the you’ll-never-get-a-job argument, I think that’s a pretty dated viewpoint. This is the 21st century, people: the word “tattoo” is not synonymous with unemployment. I have tattooed friends and they all manage to work for a living. Older folks will still hold onto their negative opinions regarding tattoos, but as my generation grows older, I suspect that tattoos will become more and more innocuous until they’re just a common everyday thing, like pierced ears, that fails to offend anyone. And if an employer can’t look past your tattoos to see your qualifications and personality, then that particular job probably wouldn’t be a good fit for you, anyway.

via

Kaelah of Little Chief Honeybee was featured on Tattoo Tuesday, and I think she sums it up best:

Undoubtedly, heavily tattooed people will run into the more conservative types who think if you’re tattooed then you’re quite obviously in a biker gang or recently sprung from prison, but I think that’s one reason I’m so drawn to the lifestyle. I wear dresses every day; I don’t even own a pair of pants. I try to portray myself as a classy young lady and full of femininity. I try to show the naysayers that they couldn’t be more wrong about tattooed women (or people in general). The most common thing I get is “How are you going to find a job?!” but I simply assure them that I have chosen a field which is much more understanding of body modifications and if I had to hide who I was at work, how on earth could I be happy doing that for a living?

I’m right there with ya, girl. Truer words were never spoken.

item.title: starry night
item.dc:creator: Ugnius
item.description: Picture was taken at night on the Klaipėda city pier. Exposure was only 30 s so the stars were still round shape. In composition there are more than 2/3 of the night sky, because it was amazingly starry.
item.content:encoded: Picture was taken at night on the Klaipėda city pier. Exposure was only 30 s so the stars were still round shape. In composition there are more than 2/3 of the night sky, because it was amazingly starry.

item.title: Chernobyl: No Haven for Wildlife
item.dc:creator: kendracnn
item.description: Today marks 25 years since the worst nuclear accident in history.  On April 26, 1986, a reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in Ukraine exploded, killing at least 30 people and sending hundreds of others to the hospital.  Soviet authorities evacuated 200,000 people from the area, and set up an exclusion zone the size of [...]
item.content:encoded:
Today marks 25 years since the worst nuclear accident in history.  On April 26, 1986, a reactor at the Chernobyl nuclear plant in Ukraine exploded, killing at least 30 people and sending hundreds of others to the hospital.  Soviet authorities evacuated 200,000 people from the area, and set up an exclusion zone the size of Switzerland around the crippled plant.  Millions of people were exposed to radiation, and thousands developed thyroid cancer.  Despite that, the United Nations says there has been no major public health impact in the decades since the accident.  But radiation experts say the true health costs of the disaster are still unknown.

Anecdotal evidence suggests beavers, deer, hawks, eagles and other wildlife have returned to the Chernobyl exclusion zone in abundance since people fled the area in 1986.  But one radiation ecologist says that picture is misleading.  Biology Professor Tim Mousseau of the University of South Carolina says biodiversity in the area around Chernobyl has dropped dramatically since the meltdown.  Last year, he and his colleagues published a census of wildlife in the exclusion zone.  He talked with BackStory about his findings.

item.title: Gaudi: Shaping Barcelona’s Architecture
item.dc:creator: Krysia Johnstone
item.description: I have always had an interest in Architecture.  In fact I was almost an architecture major but I decided that my appreciation for architecture was not enough for me to want to be an architect.  Barcelona has reminded me how much I enjoy simply observing buildings.  Every corner you turn here there is another amazing [...]
item.content:encoded:
I have always had an interest in Architecture.  In fact I was almost an architecture major but I decided that my appreciation for architecture was not enough for me to want to be an architect.  Barcelona has reminded me how much I enjoy simply observing buildings.  Every corner you turn here there is another amazing building; the key is to look up.  Since the buildings are so old most of them contain statues in the corners, or balconies with beautiful ornamentation.

The amazing part about Barcelona’s architecture is everything is reused and renovated, it seems that no space goes to waste.  The old Hospital Sant Pau was built in 1410 now houses the National Library of Catalonia.  The newer Hospital Sant Pau is currently under renovation to become a museum and cultural center, and so Barcelona built its newest Hospital San Pau right next door.  The Sagrada Familia is still under going construction, and the Roman Ruins have been converted into parts of markets and museums.  Everything seems to be exposed and yet hidden all at the same time.

Barcelona has a large range of Architecture because it has been around for many centuries, and before it was an established city, many groups tried to take over the area.  This created the many different building types in Barcelona.  Barcelona’s most famous architect  is Antoni Gaudi.  Gaudi is the essence of the Art Nouveau movement in Catalonia called Modernisme.  While walking the streets of Barcelona any building built after about 1900 has some touch of Gaudi in it.  Gaudi’s main works are Casa Batllo, Casa Mila, Park Guell, and the Sagrada Familia.  When visiting Barcelona it is essential to at least see the outside of all of these buildings, and definitely go visit Park Guell.

Antoni Gaudi was born in Tarragona, and grew up in Spain.  He was a devout catholic, so much so that he devoted his later years solely to the Christian Faith in the making of the Sagrada Familia.  If we look at any of Gaudi’s works there is a huge importance placed on nature.  This is because Gaudi believed that by working with nature he was working with the Creator, god, and so all of his works show the natural curves of nature rather than geometric shapes.

Casa Batllo, or House of Bones, is Gaudi’s earliest famous work.  It was built from 1904 to 1906 and is located at Passeig de Gracia, 43.  It is located on the Block of Discord, which is a well-known block because it has four famous architects buildings right next to each other.  It starts with Lluís Domènech i Montaner’s Casa Lleó-Morera, then comes Enric Sagnier’s Casa Mulleras, next is Josep Puig i Cadafalch’s  Casa Amatller, and last is Antoni Gaudí’s Casa Batllo.  Casa Batllo is called the House of Bones because the façade has a rather skeletal feel.  The façade also has a beautiful trencadis design that starts in a golden orange color and moves into a blue and green color.  Trencadis is a type of mosaic created from broken tile shards, a style Gaudi really enjoyed using.  As many buildings in Barcelona, there is some recognition to Saint George. On the roof of Casa Batllo is a large arch that as the story goes is supposed to be the dragon’s tail that Saint George kills.  Casa Batllo is in walking distance from Casa Mila.

Casa Mila, also known as La Pedrera (Catalan for The Query), was built between 1905 and 1910 and it is located at Passeig de Gracia, 91 in the  Eixample district.  During this time period it was common for houses to be named after the owner, the owner of Casa Mila was Pere Mila.  Pere Mila saw Casa Batllo and then asked Gaudi to commission a building for himself.  This building was originally planned to be a religious structure, but the government at the time disagreed with many of the religious aspects and so Gaudi’s original plan was not followed.  One of the amazing features of this building is that there is not one straight line.  By not using load-bearing walls (what normal buildings use), Gaudi used a combination of arches, pillars, and steel so that he could create a much more irregular floor plan.  The outside of the building is noticeable because it looks almost like a wave.  Since it is hard to get light to the inside of the structure Gaudi built two courtyards in which cars used to be able to drive into.  The roof terrace is another stunning feature of this building.  It has many chimneys that look as if they have faces on them, as well as bench that one can sit at to look out all over Barcelona.

Park Guell is not a building, but a park that Gaudi designed, built from 1900 to 1914 and it is located in the Gracia district of Barcelona.  Originally this site was built for a housing complex inspired by the English Garden City movement. There was supposed to be sixty triangular lots for luxury housing, but only two were built, one house was Gaudi’s home from 1906 – 1926.  There are many remarkable features and structures in this park.  When you walk in the main entrance there are two buildings with odd-shaped rooftops and beautiful trencadis coloring.  As you keep walking straight in, you come across a famous statue/fountain in the park, the dragon. Keep walking in and you end up in a cooler covered structure with mosaics both on the ceilings and floor.  A fun thing to do is put your camera on the floor and take a self-timed picture of you and your friends with the mosaics of the ceiling in the center.  The next thing you will find is a road leading up to the look out point.  This road is covered with inverted arches that look like tree trunks. On the wall opposite the tree trunks are little “nests” were many people like to take pictures.  As you reach the look out area it can be noted that the set up is rather odd, the bench is curved again in a wave-like shape.  This is purposefully done in order to create privacy for each group of people.

Gaudi’s last project was the Sagrada Familia.  This is his most famous work, and it is not even completed.  The Sagrada Familia started being built in 1882, but Gaudi only got involved in 1883, in 1926 when he died less than a quarter of the project was finished.  Its projected finish date is 2026 but it hard because the building of the Sagrada Familia is relying on very small funds.  In 1936 the construction of the Sagrada Familia came to a halt because of the Spanish Civil War and with this some of Gaudi’s original construction plans were lost as well.  The building has three main facades – the Nativity façade, the Passion façade and the Glory façade.  The Nativity façade was constructed between 1894 and 1930 and it is dedicated to the birth of Jesus.  This façade faces the rising sun to the northeast, another symbol of Jesus’ birth.  It is divided into three porticos – hope, faith, and charity.  The Passion façade is much more plain and simple.  It is dedicated to Christ’s suffering and this shown thought the depiction of his skeletal body.  This façade faces the setting sun, indicating the death of Christ.  The Glory façade is the largest façade and will be the principal façade with access to the central nave. This façade will depict the road of God to show that those who do not choose his path will end up in a worse off place. Construction on this façade began in 2002.

Antoni Gaudi has shaped the architecture of Barcelona, which has shaped Barcelona as a city.  When the Sagrada Familia is finally finished it will be the end of Gaudi’s era.  Who will come next?

item.title: 3,650 Day Anniversary
item.dc:creator: liztesar
item.description: Today, I celebrate 10 years with my best friend.  10 years ago today, I asked Tim to go steady and he said yes.  3,650 days later, here we are. How did we spend 3,650 days?  We’ve been through so much and have had so much fun along the way! Here’s a look back. What’s the best way [...]
item.content:encoded:
Today, I celebrate 10 years with my best friend.  10 years ago today, I asked Tim to go steady and he said yes.  3,650 days later, here we are.

How did we spend 3,650 days?  We’ve been through so much and have had so much fun along the way!

Here’s a look back.

Click to view slideshow.

What’s the best way to celebrate 10 years? We had a great trip last weekend in Orlando, so tonight we laid low.  I made our favorite dinner – tater tot casserole.  It’s SO YUMMY!!! It’s not the healthiest, so we can’t make it very often.

How long have you been together with your significant other?  How do you celebrate the years?

item.title: … – - – … SOS … – - – …
item.dc:creator: Larry's blog
item.description: This photo of my father was taken in 1967, one of the earliest photos of my “career”, and one of many old slides I’ve been finding in my archeological dig known as “the closet”.  I mention “slide” because slide film was for serious photographs, not “snapshots” that were taken with film, printed and possibly saved in a scrapbook, but most likely lost or [...]
item.content:encoded:
Hamming It Up

 This photo of my father was taken in 1967, one of the earliest photos of my “career”, and one of many old slides I’ve been finding in my archeological dig known as “the closet”.  I mention “slide” because slide film was for serious photographs, not “snapshots” that were taken with film, printed and possibly saved in a scrapbook, but most likely lost or discarded.  No, if you used slide film you intended the photograph to be a keeper, something that got special attention –stored in a tray with slots for each slide and only brought out to be shown during a slide show, which meant setting up the  expensive projector (praying the bulb would work) and bulky shiny-white screen that rolled out of a long metal cannister and then hung on spindly collapsible metal legs. 

If you were going to show slides you were going to set up for a real show, settle in for a while with popcorn and pop.  Popcorn actually popped on your own stove using cooking oil in a deep pot and popcorn kernals, you know, corn that comes from a cob that grows on a tall green stalk, a special variety of corn that held a lot of mositure in the kernal so it would “pop” when heated.  Pop was sparingly poured over ice cubes into a plastic Tupperware glass.  Second helpings of pop were unheard of.  I’m talking about a show that included the whole family and best friends invited over to see your vacation slides, you know, two or three carousels that held 120 slides each.  Taking slides was serious business, and shows were reserved for unusually polite people with a high tolerance for boredom.  But, I digress.

I’ve spent most of this past winter going through every slide I could find in the house so I could either discard it or scan it for future generations.  I thought this slide was a decent picture, fairly well-composed with detail in the shadows and highlights.  My dad was a radio man in the navy during WW II and continued as a ham radio hobbyist for many years after.  He used military surplus equipment to cobble together his “rig” that could transmit and receive messages around the world.  None of his equipment came in a “rice box” (slang in those days for “Made in Japan”), all of it was American made.  Notice how much space his equipment required, all of which would probably fit in today’s cheap cell phone.  And, of course, the ubiquitous ash tray that was common during that era.

His “commo shack” was in the basement, right next door to my bedroom and my bed was on the other side of the wall where he sat.  He preferred Morse Code even though voice transmittal was becoming more common; I think there was sort of an informal fraternity of old guys, vets probably, that hung on to using code because it separated them from the young rookies who were too lazy to learn Morse Code.  He was a “brass pounder” (using a key like an old telegraph), which was noisy and I fell asleep most nights with a symphony of dots and dashes reverberating through the wall. 

Ham operators had their own language of shortcuts to minimize the number of keystrokes it took to send a message.   They were the original “texters”, using a lot of acronyms that must have been heavily influenced by their military experience.  A few examples of the shortcuts are:  SASE = self addressed stamped envelope, WX = weather, OT = old timer, 73 = best regards, FB = fine business, good, okay, or swell, 88 = hugs and kisses, YL = young lady, and XYL = wife.  I guess the modern day “telegraphers” (texters) have nothing on the old radio men.

Thought for the day:   Man invented language to satisfy his deep need to complain.  Lily Tomlin


Tagged: Family & Friends, humor, photojournalism

item.title: Tuesdays with Dorie: Strawberry-Rhubarb Double Crisp
item.dc:creator: steph (whisk/spoon)
item.description: We’re in that weird in-between time of year when there really isn’t any good fruit here.  The rhubarb has still not made its long-awaited (for me anyway) appearance at my Greenmarket, and the leftover apples just look like they’ve been banging around in storage for the last few months.  This Strawberry-Rhubarb Double Crisp is so tasty that I wanted to make [...]
item.content:encoded:
We’re in that weird in-between time of year when there really isn’t any good fruit here.  The rhubarb has still not made its long-awaited (for me anyway) appearance at my Greenmarket, and the leftover apples just look like they’ve been banging around in storage for the last few months.  This Strawberry-Rhubarb Double Crisp is so tasty that I wanted to make it again this past week before TWD posting, filled with whatever, but I couldn’t find any fruit that really spoke to me.  Luckily, I do have a crisp to show you…one that I made at the end of last May, when the rhubarb was still around and the strawberries were red through and through.  The combination made for an intensely colored and flavored fruit filling.

If you’d like to know what the heck a “double crisp” is, it’s a crisp with a topping AND a crust…so that makes it double good.  In addition to the usual suspects like oats and nuts, this crisp mix has a gingery zip to it, which I king of dug, but if it’s not your thing, simply leave it out.

For the recipe, see Baking: From My Home to Yours by Dorie Greenspan (it’s also here on NPR’s site) or read Teapots and Cake Stands, as it was Sarah’s pick this week.  Don’t forget to check out the TWD Blogroll!

item.title: How Does Your Garden Grow?
item.dc:creator: bethwand
item.description: Remember this? The  beautiful lettuce table that Peter built for me in January? Well! Now it looks like this: It’s lush with lettuce and strawberries! I feel like our gardening adventures are serving their purpose too – when I asked Bay if she would like a strawberry, she ran out the back door to the [...]
item.content:encoded:
Remember this?

The  beautiful lettuce table that Peter built for me in January? Well! Now it looks like this:

It’s lush with lettuce and strawberries! I feel like our gardening adventures are serving their purpose too – when I asked Bay if she would like a strawberry, she ran out the back door to the plant! The lettuce is very tasty too. We’ve had salads at every meal.

The Freesia  and Star Jasmine scent the backyard with their sweet smell. We have blooms and fruit on the tomato plants and the Ocotillo is in full bloom too. And I also found a new addition, a tomatillo plant! Can’t wait for Peter’s delicious salsa verde. In short, our yard is smelling and tasting pretty delicious right now.

Freesia

Jasmine

The Ocotillo. It’s the lone survivor from our remodel. To give you an idea of its size, the wall next to it is 15 feet tall.

Blooms up close

Yummy heirloom tomatoes

Tomatillo – heloooo green enchiladas!
